page.title: 16UPMINSTER : URBAN TRANSITION
page.content: Upminster was still a{farming {community}until the railway came in 1885. Gradually it lost its agri- cultural associations becoming a {dormitory suburb.}Houses near the station date from{1900,}those east of Corbets Tey Road from about{1930.} Shops and offices around the Station Road cross-roads serve this community, together with several schools, including Upminster Primary and Gaynes Secondary, both dating from the 1920s. {The principal roads, St.Mary's Lane, {Corbets Tey Road and Clay Tye Road {have existed for centuries, appearing {on 17th century maps.}Names have changed, as have road surfaces; 19th century lanes have been tarred and have traffic signs. Some{pre-1900} housing still exists beside these roads.
